_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



The stationary source and regulated substances handled 



The Eastman Jefferson site produces hydrocarbon resins from organic feedstocks which are used in a variety of adhesive applications.  RMP-regulated substances handled on site are 1,3-Pentadiene, 2-Methylpropene, Hydrogen, and Anhydrous Ammonia.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source

Eastman is a member of the American Chemistry Council and subscribes to the principles of Responsible Care.  Our accidental release prevention and emergency response polices are found in the Responsible Care Pledge which reads in part:

We pledge:

?    To lead our Company in ethical ways that increasingly benefit society, the economy and the environment.

?    To design and develop products that can be manufactured, transported, used and disposed of or recycled safely.

?    To work with customers, carriers, suppliers, distributors and contractors to foster the safe and secure use, transport and disposal of chemicals and provide hazard and risk information that can be accessed and applied in their operations and products.

?    To design and operate our facilities in a safe, secure and environmentally sound manner.

?    To instill a culture throughout all levels of our organization to continually identify, reduce and manage process safety risks.

?    To promote pollution prevention, minimization of waste and conservation of energy and other critical resources at every stage of the life cycle of our products.

?    To cooperate with governments at all levels and organizations in the development of effective and efficient safety, health, environmental and security laws, regulations and standards.

?    To support education and research on the health, safety, environmental effects and security of our products and processes.

?    To communicate product, service and process risks to our stakeholders and listen to and consider their perspectives.

?    To make continual progress toward o

ur goal of no accidents, injuries or harm to human health and the environment from our products and operations and to be transparent in reporting our health, safety, environmental and security performance.

?    To seek continual improvement in our integrated Responsible Care Management System; to address environmental, health, safety and security performance.

?    To promote Responsible Care; by encouraging and assisting others to adhere to Responsible Care Principles.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps



The Jefferson Site's general accidental release prevention program includes:

?    Designing for safety including redundant safety systems

?    Use of automatic and manual shutoff valves

?    Conducting Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs) studies on production areas

?    Manual and automatic fire suppression systems

?    Site-wide preventive maintenance and mechanical integrity programs

?    Use of recommissioning checklists

Chemical-specific measures include:

?    Use of combustible gas analyzers and excess flow valves on the 2-methylpropene storage tank

?    Use of ammonia detectors and excess flow valves on the anhydrous ammonia tank

?    In-tank automatic foam suppression systems in 1,3-pentadiene storage tanks

?    Fusible links which melt in a fire at the hydrogen storage area as well as piping all vents and reliefs to a safe location 



The five-year accident history



The Jefferson Site experienced one accident in the past five years.  The incident occurred on June 6, 2015 and involved the release of 150 lbs. of 1,3-pentadiene.  Residents were instructed to shelter in place as a precautionary measure.



The emergency response program



The Jefferson Site maintains an on-site Emergency Response Team which is trained to respond to fires, accidental releases, and confined space entry rescues.  The site also maintains a fire truck, a confined space rescue vehicle, and a hazmat response vehicle which are always available on site

.  In addition, the site has entered into mutual aid agreements with local fire departments in the event that outside resources are needed to respond to an emergency.



Planned changes to improve safety



There are no current planned changes to improve safety systems related to RMP-covered chemicals.
